text:
Borealis has announced the global rollout of its advanced Borstar® Digital Twin program, setting a new benchmark for the use of artificial intelligence and digitalization in industrial operations. This initiative reflects Borealis’ continued commitment to pushing the limits of digital innovation by embedding AI-driven intelligence directly into core production processes. The worldwide deployment of the Borstar Digital Twin represents a major step forward in transforming how manufacturing plants operate, make decisions, and continuously improve performance.

At its core, the Borstar Digital Twin is a sophisticated suite of digital solutions that merges cutting-edge technology with Borealis’ deep expertise in process engineering. By combining artificial intelligence, real-time optimization tools, and advanced data analytics, the platform delivers a highly accurate virtual representation of the physical production process. This digital replica allows plants to monitor operations in real time, anticipate future process behavior, and run advanced simulations without disrupting actual production. As a result, Borealis facilities can achieve new levels of efficiency, productivity, and operational reliability.

The capabilities of the Borstar Digital Twin extend across multiple dimensions of plant performance. It supports data-driven decision-making by enabling operators and engineers to optimize processes using predictive insights and scenario-based simulations. Safety is enhanced through early identification and prediction of potential process or equipment issues, allowing preventive action before problems escalate. Sustainability objectives are also strengthened, as the system helps reduce waste, lower energy consumption, and minimize overall environmental impact. In addition, the platform accelerates innovation by shortening product development cycles and enabling virtual operator training in a risk-free digital environment.

The Borstar Digital Twin program was initially launched in 2023, with a specific focus on Borealis’ proprietary Borstar® technology used in the production of polyethylene and polypropylene. From the outset, the program was designed to ensure that production plants operate at peak efficiency while maintaining consistently high product quality. By 2025, Borealis reached a digital maturity milestone that made it possible to scale this solution globally. The program is now being rolled out across all Borstar units worldwide, including those operated by licensees such as Baystar™ and Borouge. This global expansion signals a new phase in which digital tools and AI-enabled workflows are becoming standard practice within Borealis’ core manufacturing operations.

According to Wolfram Krenn, Executive Vice President Operations at Borealis, the adoption of the Borstar Digital Twin goes far beyond simply introducing new technology. He explains that by integrating AI-based predictions with rigorous process models, plants can operate more efficiently, execute faster and more controlled grade transitions, and consistently deliver prime-quality products. Real-time monitoring also enables early detection and mitigation of process deviations or equipment anomalies, reducing unplanned shutdowns and improving overall reliability.

From a strategic perspective, Borealis CEO Stefan Doboczky highlights the broader value of the initiative. He emphasizes that the Borstar Digital Twin transforms advanced technology into a tangible customer benefit by delivering greater speed, reliability, and quality. In doing so, the program directly supports Borealis’ We4Customers strategy, reinforcing the company’s focus on customer success while strengthening its competitive position in the global polymers market.

Salvador Bahia Airport becomes Brazil’s first to supply Sustainable Aviation Fuel for regular flights

0

SHARES

Posted: 22 December 2025 | Gabriel Higgins |

Starting November, Salvador Bahia Airport supplies SAF for daily Gol and LATAM flights, reducing emissions and reinforcing Brazil’s commitment to sustainable aviation practices

Credit: VINCI Airports

Salvador Bahia Airport (SSA), part of VINCI Airports’ network since 2018, is pioneering Brazil’s aviation decarbonisation by becoming the country’s first airport to supply Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) for commercial operations. Regular use of SAF begins this November, marking a significant milestone for both the airport and VINCI Airports’ commitment to accelerating the energy transition across its mobility infrastructure and stakeholders.

The airport already serves as a regional benchmark for environmental performance. It was the first in the Americas to achieve the highest level of Airport Carbon Accreditation, ACA 5, implementing advanced practices for carbon management and reduction. More than 15 airports in the VINCI network now offer SAF, and Salvador Bahia’s introduction of regular SAF operations further strengthens its environmental position and aligns with decarbonisation goals across the network.

In Brazil, SAF is commercially distributed by Vibra. The fuel blend used at Salvador meets international sustainability criteria and can help lower lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions compared to conventional jet fuel. Two daily flights from Salvador Bahia, operated by Gol Linhas Aéreas and LATAM Airlines Brasil, now use a blend of 10 per cent pure SAF and 90 per cent conventional jet fuel, the highest proportion currently applied in Brazilian aviation. The pure SAF, produced from used cooking oil, is presently the only type available nationally. While flight emissions fall under airlines’ scope 1 and the airport’s scope 3, the renewable fuel reduces lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions and represents a first step in expanding SAF use in Brazil.

Governor Jerônimo Rodrigues said, “Bahia has made significant progress in clean energy production and in building a more sustainable future, where development and social justice move forward together.”

Julio Ribas, CEO of VINCI Airports in Brazil, added, “SAF is currently the most effective tool for reducing emissions in commercial aviation. Being able to offer flights fuelled with SAF in Salvador on a continuous basis places Bahia at the forefront of the energy transition and reinforces our commitment to transforming passenger journeys with increasingly sustainable solutions.”

text:
Billions of dollars in federal investments, including tax credits and funds authorized through legislation such as the Inflation Reduction Act and Bipartisan Infrastructure Law, have stimulated private investment in clean energy deployment. Now federal priorities are shifting, narrowing the federal incentives available for climate and clean energy investments. To deploy more innovative energy technologies for U.S. energy security, resilience, and growth, it is crucial to understand how shifts in federal policy and executive actions impact private investment. CATF’s new clean energy investment tracker is designed to do just that.

This tool tracks private investments that have been catalyzed by federal incentives and those that have been canceled while also tracking how changes to federal policy and executive actions impact the range of federal incentives available to projects. The data for this tracker comes from Rhodium’s Clean Investment Monitor combined with CATF’s data and analysis of federal incentives.

Federal incentives may be impacted by legislation and agency actions, which can limit project access to tax credits, grants, and loans. Where CATF has identified federal incentives as impacted by federal actions, the tracker labels project investments eligible for these incentives as “incentive eligibility impacted” (see top dashboard and status filter for investment totals for this label, and project details showing impacted incentives when selecting a project on the tracker to learn more). This label does not mean a project will not move forward, but that federal support is being withheld in some way. This information is essential to understand how federal activities impact private investments.

What’s impacting investments this quarter?

Federal legislation

Through the enactment of the One Big Beautiful Bill Act (OBBBA) in July 2025, many clean energy tax credits were repealed or narrowed by new restrictions and/or accelerated phasedowns. The table below summarizes key changes to the tax credits:

Executive actions

The following executive agency actions could limit access to many of these tax credits, depending how they are implemented.

Proposed EPA Rule: Reconsideration of the Greenhouse Gas Reporting Program (GHGRP). On September 12, 2025, EPA proposed to permanently remove program reporting obligations for 46 of 47 source categories of the GHGRP. EPA’s proposal also includes permanently removing the natural gas distribution segment of the petroleum and natural gas source category (subpart W) and suspending reporting of the remaining nine subpart W segments until reporting year 2034. The Treasury Department and IRS rely on the GHGRP to administer Section 45Q Carbon Sequestration Tax Credits, Section 45V Clean Hydrogen Tax Credits, and Section 45Y Clean Electricity Tax Credits. Revising the GHGRP as proposed could hinder compliance with tax credit reporting requirements reliant on GHGRP data, and therefore the ability to claim the credits, unless IRS regulations are revised, and/or sufficient alternatives for measurement, reporting, and verification (MRV) and lifecycle analysis (LCA) are implemented.

Prohibited Foreign Entities (PFE)/Foreign Entity of Concern (FEOC) provisions. FEOC is shorthand for a type of tax provision that restricts entities with ties to certain countries considered national security threats from claiming or otherwise benefiting from federal clean energy tax credits. Previously, the IRA applied FEOC restrictions only to the 30D clean vehicle credit. OBBBA expanded upon IRA’s FEOC definition and created two new categories of Prohibited Foreign Entities (PFEs): (1) Specified Foreign Entities and (2) Foreign Influenced Entities. PFE/FEOC restrictions added by OBBBA apply to six energy tax credits: 45U, 45Y, 48E, 45X, 45Q, and 45Z, increasing compliance burdens and impacting projects claiming those credits, including enhanced geothermal and advanced nuclear. Treasury and IRS have yet to publish implementation guidance, contributing to industry uncertainty on compliance. A recent market analysis found that industry preparation is underway, but only 38% of firms surveyed describe themselves as “fully prepared” to comply with PFE/FEOC rules for 2026.

DOE announced project funding cuts and additional cuts being considered for existing awards. DOE canceled federal cost-share funding for hundreds of existing grant awards. In May and early October, DOE announced it was rescinding awards (grants and loans). Another leaked list, yet unconfirmed by DOE, was reported later in October. These nationwide funding cuts impact industrial and transportation sectors, near-term infrastructure deployment of solar and wind and grid resiliency projects, as well as methane pollution reduction investments. It is currently unknown which projects will ultimately proceed without the relied upon federal cost-share from DOE. Private sector and state level cost-share investments into these projects also face risk.

Findings

The majority of federal incentives driving private investments are impacted by recent federal activities, including OBBBA tax credit provisions, uncertainty in Treasury’s approach to PFE/FEOC implementation, EPA’s proposed GHGRP rollback, and DOE’s announced and reported cancellations of funding.

Sectors impacted by these federal actions include electric power, manufacturing, and energy and industry, which include transportation throughout. In Q3 2025, new manufacturing investment totaled $10 billion in actual investment and project cancellations totaled $2 billion, mostly from the cancellation of battery manufacturing projects. New energy and industry sector investment totaled $25 billion in actual investment in Q3, and project cancellations totaled $2 billion, primarily solar, storage, and hydrogen projects.

Read on for a few sector snapshots of how federal activities are currently impacting investments.

Electric power

Solar and wind

Utility-scale solar, together with storage installations, accounted for most clean electricity investments, and wind investments increased over 30% from the previous quarter. This is partly driven by projects accelerating timelines to fit within narrowed eligibility timelines, which is accelerating timelines, distorting supply chains, and raising costs but not driving new projects. However, recent federal actions are driving deep uncertainty for these industries with still unknown consequences for private investments in solar and wind. In particular, OBBBA narrows the time horizons for wind and solar projects (to commence construction by July 4, 2026, or be placed in service by December 31, 2027) to access the 45Y and 48E tax credits, eliminates eligibility for wind components sold after December 31, 2027 for 45X tax credit access, and creates uncertainty related to PFE/FEOC implementation. Uncertainty in solar investment will also have implications for battery investment and deployment, even if incentives for battery technologies remain largely intact.

Additionally, while most solar and wind projects are on private land, they can be sited on federal lands or otherwise require federal permits. Recent executive actions, such as the U.S. Department of the Interior Secretary’s Order prioritizing permits based on an energy project’s capacity density and the requirements for the Secretary of the Interior to personally sign off on solar and wind projects on federal lands could severely limit the solar and wind sectors’ ability to secure necessary permits. The administration has also taken several steps to slow or stop the development of offshore wind projects, which require federal approvals as they are sited in federal waters. The administration issued a halt on project approvals – a move a federal judge recently deemed unlawful – and has issued stop work orders on projects already under construction. These tax credit and permitting uncertainties upend the federal policy environment for solar and wind projects.

Looking ahead

DOE’s October project cuts announcement and additional project awards being considered for termination will likely affect wind and solar investments. EPA recently terminated the $7 billion Solar for All program within the Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund. These cuts are a withdrawal of federal support for communities across the country that applied for and received funding support to invest in these technologies.

Manufacturing

Fueling equipment and zero emission vehicles

While zero emission vehicle supply chains drove manufacturing investments in Q3 2025, these investment numbers were likely tied to investors taking action prior to the September 30, 2025, termination of 30D Clean Vehicle, 25E Previously-Owned Clean Vehicle, and 45W Commercial Clean Vehicle tax credits. OBBBA’s PFE/FEOC restrictions apply to the 45Y, 48E, and 45X tax credits that incentivize investment in the EV manufacturing supply chain – including critical minerals and batteries – creating investment uncertainty in those sectors while the industry waits for Treasury to release guidance that explains how they are implementing FEOC restrictions. The additional narrowing of the 48C Advanced Energy Project credit and the June 30, 2026, termination of the 30C Alternative Fuel Vehicle Refueling Property credit creates further uncertainty for future investments in fuel fabrication, fueling equipment, and EVs.

Separately, the administration continues to withdraw federal support for zero-emission vehicles and charging infrastructure. In addition to actions earlier this year to delay the release of funds for EV charging stations, the October DOE project cancellations further target EV supply chains for producing low-carbon fuels, building EV charging and freight corridors, and electrifying heavy-duty and public transit fleets.

Energy and industry

Sustainable aviation fuel

Investment in sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) technology continued to decline in Q3 2025. While OBBBA extended the 45Z tax credit through 2029, it dramatically reduced the maximum per-gallon credit value available to SAF producers from $1.75/gallon to $1.00/gallon, limiting the incentive for domestic investment in new or expanded SAF facilities. OBBBA also amended 45Z to require feedstocks to be from the U.S., Canada, or Mexico. The SAF industry had been positioned to expand, but these changes create new uncertainties for the domestic SAF industry.

Hydrogen

Q3 2025 hydrogen investments also declined from Q2, but hydrogen investments still comprised the majority of industry sector announcements. Subsequent quarters are likely to illustrate more of the impacts from recent federal actions, such as the OBBBA’s 45V Clean Hydrogen Credit phasedown (terminating the credit for projects that begin construction after December 31, 2027, instead of the original phaseout in 2033).

EPA’s proposed rollback of the GHGRP could impact the ability of carbon-based hydrogen projects to claim 45Q or 45V, and hydrogen projects seeking to claim 45V. The proposed delay of subpart W until reporting year 2034 would negatively impact the ability of taxpayers to receive higher incentives for better performance (i.e. lower-emissions hydrogen production) and potentially render some projects uneconomical. Carbon-based hydrogen projects can opt to claim either 45V or 45Q Carbon Sequestration tax credits; if the GHGRP is rolled back and data from subpart W is no longer available, 45Q may be the better route, but 45Q also relies on GHGRP to verify tax credit eligibility.

DOE’s announced hydrogen funding cuts in October, and the additional cuts being considered, are destabilizing for the U.S. hydrogen sector and may further alter 2025 Q4 investment data for the hydrogen sector. The announced cuts and additional cuts under consideration include eliminating federal cost share for all of the Regional Clean Hydrogen Hubs as well as 76 other hydrogen projects that support the buildout of a domestic hydrogen industry. It is unclear if projects will be able to move forward without federal cost share; at least one Hydrogen Hub announced it would pause activities in response to recent changes, including DOE’s decision to cut federal funding. Exxon announced it was halting plans for its blue hydrogen facility in Baytown, Texas – a project selected to receive up to ~$322 million in federal-cost share from DOE that was terminated in the spring.

Carbon management

Q3 2025 carbon management investments were slightly lower than Q2 levels. While OBBBA maintained the 45Q Carbon Sequestration tax credit and even included parity for enhanced oil recovery, other recent federal actions, including EPA’s proposed GHGRP rollback and DOE project cuts, have contributed to industry investment uncertainty.

Recent reporting indicates that Treasury and the IRS plan to issue guidance by the end of 2025 to clarify how taxpayers can verify their projects by an independent engineer or geologist to meet the 45Q credit requirement for tax year 2025. Until that guidance is finalized, there will be no way for taxpayers to substantiate 45Q claims if the GHGRP is eliminated.

text:
Denmark has condemned the United States’ decision to appoint a special envoy to Greenland, calling the move “totally unacceptable” and summoning the US ambassador for explanations.

The reaction followed the nomination by US President Donald Trump of Louisiana republican Governor Jeff Landry as special envoy to Greenland, the autonomous Danish territory that the former president has repeatedly suggested should become part of the United States.

Danish Foreign Minister Lars Løkke Rasmussen said he was “deeply angry” about the appointment, adding that Copenhagen would formally raise the issue with Washington in the coming days.

Trump announced the nomination on his Truth Social platform, arguing that Greenland was of strategic importance to US national security. He said Landry would work to defend American interests, as well as those of US allies.

Danish MEP Anders Vistisen told Brussels Signal that the appointment reflected what he described as a flawed view of national security.

“Contrary to what US President Trump thinks, the territories of other countries are not put there simply to geographically defend the United States,” he said, adding that Denmark was a committed NATO member whose soldiers had taken part in alliance missions.

While Denmark shared concerns about the growing influence of China and Russia in the Arctic, Vistisen said this did not justify what he described as expansionist rhetoric directed at a NATO ally.

He stressed that Greenland was both an integral and autonomous part of the Kingdom of Denmark and that its status was not up for negotiation. “It is not for sale, nor is it an item to be robbed,” he said.

Greenland governs its own domestic affairs, while Denmark retains responsibility for foreign policy, defence and security. Decisions affecting the territory’s international position are traditionally taken with both Danish and Greenlandic representatives involved.

US interest in Greenland has intensified since Trump returned to office in January, with the president repeatedly citing national security concerns to justify his claims. Danish media have recently reported efforts by Washington to establish more direct contacts with Greenland’s government, a move that has caused unease in Copenhagen.

Landry posted on X that it was an honour to take on the role, adding that he would work to make Greenland “a part of the US”.

European leaders also weighed in following the announcement. Germany’s foreign ministry said it had “taken note of the new announcement” and stressed that its position remained unchanged.

“The future of Greenland lies in the hands of the Greenlanders,” a spokesperson said.

Danish Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen and Greenlandic Prime Minister Jens-Frederik Nielsen echoed that view, saying respect for sovereignty remained fundamental. “We have said it before. Now, we say it again. National borders and the sovereignty of states are rooted in international law,” they said together.

European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen and European Council President Antonio Costa reiterated calls for respect for territorial integrity

Philippine Airlines received its first Airbus A350-1000, which arrived in Manila on December 20

PAL becomes the first carrier in Southeast Asia to operate the next-generation widebody aircraft

Delivery ceremony held in Toulouse, France, led by PAL Holdings president Lucio Tan III and top executives

The new aircraft is the first of nine A350-1000s PAL ordered under its fleet expansion program

Aircraft expected to serve PAL’s transpacific routes and features tri-class cabin layout: 42 Business Class, 24 Premium Economy, 316 Economy seats (total 382 passengers)

Acquisition raises PAL’s fleet to 82 aircraft

It is capable of operating with sustainable aviation fuel, reinforcing PAL’s sustainability goals

Philippine Airlines (PAL) on December 20 took delivery of its first Airbus A350-1000, becoming the first airline in Southeast Asia to operate the next-generation widebody aircraft.

The aircraft arrived in Manila at 4:43 p.m., following a delivery ceremony in Toulouse, France, led by PAL Holdings Inc. president Lucio Tan III, PAL announced in a press release.

Tan was joined by senior company officials, including PAL board adviser Kyle Tan, PAL president Richard Nuttall, and executive vice president and chief operating officer Atty. Carlos Luis Fernandez.

The delivery is the first of nine A350-1000s PAL ordered as part of its fleet expansion program, bringing the airline’s total fleet to 82 aircraft.

READ: PAL books 62% higher income in Q3 2025

The aircraft, expected to serve PAL’s transpacific routes, features a tri-class cabin layout with 42 Business Class seats, 24 Premium Economy seats, and 316 Economy seats, accommodating up to 382 passengers.

Powered by Rolls-Royce Trent XWB-97 turbofan engines, each capable of delivering up to 97,000 pounds of thrust, the A350-1000 offers enhanced efficiency and reliability.

It also sets new standards in sustainable aviation, with up to a 25% reduction in fuel consumption and carbon dioxide emissions compared with previous-generation aircraft, and the capability to operate with sustainable aviation fuel or SAF.

READ: PAL expands international flights, capacity for December holidays

Tan expressed gratitude to Airbus, PAL’s partner for more than four decades, and underscored the significance of the milestone.

“The arrival of the A350-1000 marks a significant milestone in our ongoing commitment to fleet modernization and network growth. It will be a source of Filipino pride and a transformational step for our airline,” Tan said.

Heathrow's third runway is back on the table, and this time, this time, the government says it's serious again

Alan Leer

1 minute ago

With the news that the government is backing Heathrow's £49 billion plan for a third runway, the long running debate over airport expansion is back at the top of the agenda.

Supporters say the move is vital for UK competitiveness and future connectivity.

Critics question the environmental and community impact.

So what does this decision really mean for Britain's place in global aviation? And what happens if we don't expand?

Aviation expert and special advisor to the Secretary General of UN Tourism, Anita Menderrata, speaks to The Standard’s Tech and Science Daily podcast to help unpack the story.

The expansion of Heathrow, namely the addition of a third runway, is incredibly important to the UK as a whole.

Not just Heathrow, because it strengthens the competitiveness of the UK both in terms of travel and tourism, but also importantly trade.

A computer image of an expanded Heathrow Airport after the third runway has been built

Heathrow

Any airport that operates will have a busyness factor. It's all about the efficiency of how the busyness is managed, and this is where airport operations, airlines, and air traffic control needs to come in incredibly effectively.

So the beauty of adding in a third runway, which will only be operational in 2035, is that you can actually elevate the efficiency of the aircraft taking off and landing rather than having the risk of bottlenecks, because you now have the flexibility of a third runway, especially if for any reason any of the other runways come into any operational challenges.

The net effect will be very good because when it comes to a project like this, which is core infrastructure for a nation, it's always about the opportunity cost. It's not just should we; it’s if we don't make this investment, what will this mean for the UK economy, for all of its productivity and its identity?

So there is potentially some big national upside, but what about the people living around the airport?

The entire process of developing the third runway at Heathrow is very much about upgrading the entire infrastructure itself.

If we look at other airports in the world, whether it's JFK, Charles de Gaulle, Schiphol, those are in high density areas. Heathrow has the benefit of being outside of central London, so it actually has the environment around it to be able to stretch with minimal disruption.

Any community living on the edges effectively of an airport is going to be impacted by growth of the airport, and it's understandable that there's frustration.

The consultation process and the engagement process with the local community is vital, so they actually understand the benefits of this, not only some potential hardships they may face.

Lib Dem MPs gathered in Westminster to oppose a third Heathrow runway

.

From the middle of next year, the public consultation process is going to begin. Heathrow is needing to put through not just an economic impact assessment, but an environmental and a social impact assessment that will allow the casemaking to be clear, because once again it's about the opportunity cost of if we don't do this. Communities might stay in place, but there will be a limitation to their own growth.

It's very important that Heathrow as an airport establishment and the ecosystem around it work very closely with the community ecosystem so it's very clear the benefits. Equally, communities must be able to voice concerns they might have, in order to have those concerns answered.

But more planes equals more pollution, right? What are the environmental implications of adding a new runway to Heathrow Airport?

What's very important is that the expansion of Heathrow and the third runway actually strengthens the UK's ability when it comes to reaching net zero by 2050.

Not only is it more effective operations of the runway, it's going to be a completely electric powered terminal itself.

It's using much more efficient air traffic control, and it's bringing in the aircraft that are allowed to utilise a sustainable aviation fuel, which cuts emissions by 80%.

There will be higher traffic flows of people. But a third runway that allows for larger aircraft could actually mean fewer aircraft taking off with more people and cargo rather than increasing the number of smaller aircraft.

There will be higher traffic flows of people at an expanded Heathrow Airport

PA Archive

The interesting thing, and something that is often completely underestimated and under-celebrated, is how much the aviation industry per se is at the forefront of innovation in sustainable engineering for all other industries.

The investment that aviation has been putting into sustainability for decades now and the billions that have gone into it have gone into other modes of transport have gone into other industries. So in many ways aviation almost becomes an incubator for innovation itself.

So much learning from the Heathrow expansion will be cascaded through the UK as a whole. So this is very important.

When we look at any nation's competitiveness, productivity growth is essential. But scaling up growth does not have to mean scaling up negative environmental impact.

So ironically, while people might question why aviation is not damaging to the environment, it's actually going to help the environment because it's going to catapult the UK's ability to continue to grow through essential aviation, but through smart green aviation that works towards net zero by 2050.

title: Inside the AAPA assembly: What Asia Pacific airline CEOs are losing sleep over
description:
In November, the Association of Asia Pacific Airlines (AAPA) held its 69th Assembly of Presidents in Bangkok, bringing together airline CEOs and senior leaders from across the region.
Conversations with Asia Pacific airline leaders, however, paint a more complex picture.

IATA highlights Asia Pacific growth and air traffic management risks IATA data presented at the assembly underlined Asia Pacific’s role as the fastest-growing aviation market globally.
However, he warned that airline expansion and airport investment risk being constrained by outdated air traffic management systems.

Subscribe

Airlines across Asia Pacific are enjoying a strong rebound in passenger demand, but beneath the headline growth, chief executives are grappling with persistent supply chain disruptions, geopolitical instability, and outdated air traffic management systems.

In November, the Association of Asia Pacific Airlines (AAPA) held its 69th Assembly of Presidents in Bangkok, bringing together airline CEOs and senior leaders from across the region. The event, hosted by Bangkok Airways, was supported by major aircraft and engine OEMs, aviation experts, and international media, including Aerospace Global News.

Nearly 200 delegates attended, representing carriers including Air Astana, Air India, Air New Zealand, ANA, Cathay Pacific, China Airlines, EVA Airways, Garuda Indonesia, Japan Airlines, Lion Group, Malaysia Airlines, Philippine Airlines, Qantas, Royal Brunei, Singapore Airlines, Thai Airways, and Vietnam Airlines.

Strong passenger growth masks mounting operational pressures

With global passenger numbers now exceeding pre-pandemic levels, it would be easy to assume commercial aviation is firmly back on track. Conversations with Asia Pacific airline leaders, however, paint a more complex picture.

Across the region, airlines are struggling with delayed aircraft deliveries, engines stuck off-wing, shortages in maintenance and repair capacity, constrained spare parts availability, and difficulties sourcing trained personnel. These challenges are limiting growth just as demand accelerates.

Supply chain disruption, tariffs, and airspace closures compound costs

Opening the assembly, AAPA Director General Subhas Menon warned that fragile supply chain recovery is now being undermined by rising tariffs, driving up supplier costs while simultaneously dampening demand through inflation.

He added that regulatory burdens and military conflicts are further inflating operating costs. At various points over the past year, airspace across more than 14 countries has been closed, forcing longer routings, delays, and cancellations.

“It is an inefficient operating environment,” Menon said, warning of the risks posed by civil aircraft operating near active conflict zones, including spoofing of air navigation systems and the threat of aircraft being caught in military crossfire.

SAF ambitions clash with limited supply and high costs

Sustainability featured prominently on the agenda. AAPA airlines have committed to a collective target of 5% sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) utilisation by 2030, but concern is growing over the slow pace of supply development.

“Aviation is a hard-to-abate sector for carbon emissions, yet we are asked to rely mostly on a hard-to-get commodity called SAF,” Menon told delegates, arguing that fuel suppliers must shoulder greater responsibility for delivering SAF at scale and at competitive prices.

IATA highlights Asia Pacific growth and air traffic management risks

IATA data presented at the assembly underlined Asia Pacific’s role as the fastest-growing aviation market globally. October passenger demand grew 8.1% year-on-year in the region, compared with 2.5% in North America and 6.7% in Europe, with international traffic to and from China, Japan, and Vietnam all posting double-digit growth.

IATA Director General Willie Walsh described the region as “the largest market in the world,” accounting for around 35% of global commercial traffic. However, he warned that airline expansion and airport investment risk being constrained by outdated air traffic management systems.

Walsh also addressed safety concerns, including lithium-ion battery risks and passenger behaviour during evacuations, noting an increase in incidents involving travellers attempting to retrieve cabin baggage.

Resolutions focus on safety, sustainability, and supply chain resilience

The assembly concluded with the adoption of four resolutions covering aviation sustainability, safety, taxes and charges, and supply chain strengthening. Looking ahead, AAPA signalled a clear focus on collaboration with regulators and suppliers to improve resilience and maintain connectivity across the region.

As reported by FAN Transport News, Azzera Inc., a leader in aviation sustainability solutions, has received a significant investment from JETEX, a prominent player in the private aviation sector. This partnership was unveiled at the Dubai Airshow 2025 and aims to enhance Azzera’s carbon-management capabilities while introducing innovative sustainability tools for clients.

This will be facilitated through Azzera’s forthcoming SAF POD platform, which is designed to simplify the processes of sourcing, tracking, and certifying emissions related to SAF. This funding positions Azzera to further enhance its technology offerings and expand its global reach while providing new tools aimed at helping clients offset their emissions effectively.

As part of this partnership, JETEX will collaborate with Azzera as it begins procuring sustainable aviation fuel for its fleet early next year-a landmark step in their commitment to sustainability.

A consortium of DEME and Italian companies Savarese Costruzioni and Iterga Costruzioni Generali will perform marine works including 900 meters of offshore breakwaters, the removal of approximately 130,000 m³ of sediments, and demolition of the decaying central pier and former steel plant service buildings. Works include dredging and placing approximately 3 million m³ of sand using DEME’s advanced trailing suction hopper dredger Bonny River, which can operate at depths beyond 100 meters. Korea aims to cut carbon emissions at its international airports by 10 percent by 2030 while expanding the use of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), a government report showed Sunday.

Under the blueprint for the 2026-2030 period, set by the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure and Transport, carbon emissions at Korea's international airports are projected to reach 29.8 million tons in 2030, up 28 percent from 23.3 million tons recorded this year.

The government aims to reduce the projected amount by 10 percent, or 2.87 million tons.

text:
The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers on Friday, Dec. 19 issued a long-awaited Dakota Access Pipeline environmental impact statement, recommending that the pipeline keep operating, but with some new conditions for its Missouri River crossing in North Dakota.

The pipeline has been operating since June 2017, carrying crude oil from North Dakota’s Bakken oil field to Illinois. The Standing Rock Sioux Tribe has opposed the project and challenged it in court, citing concerns about impacts to the tribe’s Missouri River water supply.

A federal judge in 2020 revoked the easement for the pipeline crossing under the Missouri River just north of the Standing Rock reservation, requiring additional environmental study.

The 464-page environmental impact statement evaluated five alternatives, including denying the easement or rerouting the pipeline. The corps said its preferred alternative grants the easement, allowing the pipeline to keep operating, but with some additional conditions.

The recommendation is not official until after a 30-day waiting period required under the National Environmental Policy Act. After that period concludes on Jan. 20, 2026, the corps may issue a record of decision.

The options evaluated were:

Deny the easement and abandon the pipeline by removal.

Deny the easement and abandon the pipeline in place.

Grant the easement with the same conditions as the previous easement, which Dakota Access LLC prefers.

Grant the easement with additional conditions.

Construct and operate a pipeline reroute north of Bismarck.

In its analysis, the corps wrote that the fourth option, granting the easement with conditions, protects environmental resources and responds to comments raised by tribal nations.

MORE: Gevo moves priority from South Dakota to North Dakota amid Summit pipeline delays

The conditions aim to prevent an oil spill and minimize the impacts of a spill, such as implementing new leak detection technology as it becomes available and conducting groundwater monitoring and surface water sampling.

The corps held two meetings in Bismarck in November 2023 to collect public comment on the environmental impact statement. At the time, corps officials said the final statement was expected in 2024.

In interviews after those 2023 meetings, the chairs of the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe and Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe said the Dakota Access Pipeline was operating illegally without a permit and should be shut down. Tribal leaders and environmental groups have also raised concerns about an inadequate spill response plan.

North Dakota officials, meanwhile, have supported the continuing operation of the pipeline.

“After eight years of operating safely, the Dakota Access Pipeline has become an essential part of our nation’s energy infrastructure,” Gov. Kelly Armstrong said in a statement. “Its continued operation will ensure energy security and affordability for the country while providing positive economic impact that touches every North Dakotan.”

North Dakota Monitor reporters Jeff Beach and Jacob Orledge contributed to this story. This is a developing story and will be updated.

text:
You’ve been hearing a lot lately about the efforts by corn producers to expand the use of ethanol in 2026. But, there’s also a huge push by soybean growers to expand biodiesel as well.

“We are certainly working everyday on both fuels demand and opportunities,” says Caleb Ragland, President of the American Soybean Association (ASA). He is also a farmer based in Magnolia, Kentucky.

“Whether it be biodiesel, renewable diesel—there are opportunities with SAF (sustainable aviation fuel), and there’s different feed stocks that can be used in SAF,” says Ragland. “As the saying goes, ‘The rising tide lifts all boats,’ and biofuels are such an exciting opportunity for the soybean industry that we must be pursuing.”

He tells Hoosier Ag Today that he and other soybean producers will continue to press your lawmakers on Capitol Hill to pass legislation in 2026 to further expand the biofuels industry.

“We have opportunities right now that need to be completed by Congress,” says Ragland. “We have the 45Z tax credit that’s hanging out there that needs to be done. We have the Renewable Volume Obligations, RVO’s, that need to be completed. That number has been debated and beaten to death. It’s time to get the deal done.”

“We need Congress to step up and make it happen. That’s good for demand, and it brings stability and some certainty to our industry, as well, that we desperately need,” he says.

Ragland adds that the expansion of biodiesel would truly be a win for everyone.

“The American farmer is growing a product that is getting used here domestically. It’s creating fuel that is good for the environment. It’s good for the economy. It brings jobs. It brings economic opportunity to our farms, which ties back to economic opportunity for all of our rural communities. That local farmer dollar gets turned over 6-to-8 times, at least, locally. It’s also good for all of the small businesses and it’s just good for everybody involved,” says Ragland.

Indiana is home to one of the largest biodiesel production facilities in the U.S.—which is Louis Dreyfus near Claypool in Kosciusko County. The facility currently produces around 99 million gallons of biodiesel each year.

This month marked the first delivery of a 100 percent nationally produced sustainable aviation fuel with international certification.

text:
This month marked the first delivery of a 100 percent nationally produced sustainable aviation fuel with international certification.

Brazil closes 2025 with a decisive step toward the decarbonization of aviation. In early December, Petrobras announced the first production and delivery of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) fully produced in the country.

The milestone gained further relevance with the official participation of Anac (Brazil’s National Civil Aviation Agency) in the launch, reinforcing that the product meets the most rigorous international sustainability standards.

The initiative places Brazil among the countries that have taken effective steps to transform the aviation sector, one of the most complex industries when it comes to reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

What SAF is

SAF – or Sustainable Aviation Fuel – is designed to replace conventional jet fuel partially or entirely.

Its main advantage is full compatibility with aircraft and existing airport infrastructure, without the need for technical adaptations.

In practice, this allows airlines to reduce carbon emissions immediately by using a certified fuel that is internationally recognized as one of the leading solutions for decarbonizing air transport.

Fully Brazilian SAF production with international certification

Petrobras’ SAF was produced through coprocessing at the Duque de Caxias Refinery (Reduc), in Rio de Janeiro, using technical corn oil (TCO), a residual vegetable-based feedstock.

According to official data, the fuel can reduce net CO₂ emissions by up to 87 percent in the renewable portion of the product.

The Brazilian SAF received ISCC-CORSIA certification (International Sustainability and Carbon Certification – Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation), confirming its compliance with the rules of the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO).

This certification is essential for the fuel to be accepted in international operations, ensuring sustainability, traceability and quality standards recognized worldwide.

Anac reinforces regulatory certainty and credibility

Anac attended the ceremony marking Petrobras’ first SAF production and delivery, highlighting the relevance of the fuel for the future of aviation in Brazil.

According to the agency, the fact that SAF is produced entirely in the country and already meets international criteria represents an important step forward for the development of the domestic market.

In this first phase, 3,000 cubic meters (m³) of SAF were produced and sold to distributors operating at Rio de Janeiro/Galeão International Airport. This volume corresponds to approximately one day of aviation fuel consumption across airports in the state of Rio de Janeiro, demonstrating the product’s operational viability.

Contribution to global decarbonization targets

The launch of SAF comes at a strategic moment for the aviation sector.

From 2027 onward, airlines will be required to comply with CORSIA, ICAO’s global program aimed at reducing emissions from international flights. In Brazil, the use of sustainable fuels is also aligned with the guidelines established by the Future Fuel Law (Lei do Combustível do Futuro).

By anticipating SAF production and certification, Petrobras offers the domestic market a solution ready to meet future regulatory requirements, reducing dependence on imports and strengthening Brazil’s energy industry.

A tangible step forward in the just energy transition

With institutional backing from Anac and compliance with international standards set by the International Civil Aviation Organization, sustainable aviation fuel moves beyond promise and becomes a tangible part of the present and future of air transport in Brazil.

This strengthens the country’s industry and energy sovereignty, opening the way for a new cycle of innovation and sustainability in the national aviation sector.

By closing the year with this major achievement, Brazil demonstrates that it is prepared to lead the global decarbonization agenda with real, certified and competitive solutions.

Philippine Airlines Takes Delivery of First Airbus A350-1000, Becoming Southeast Asia’s First Airline to Operate the Aircraft, Advancing Their Fleet Modernization and Sustainability Growth

Philippine Airlines has officially taken delivery of its first Airbus A350-1000, a major step forward in its long-haul fleet renewal strategy. With this delivery, PAL is the first airline in Southeast Asia to take the A350-1000, which reflects its vision of furthering passengers’ interests in an efficiency-driven and sustainable travel experience. The aircraft, flown from Toulouse, France to Manila, is the first of nine A350-1000 ordered as part of the airline’s expansion program.

A Major Step in Long-Haul Fleet Modernization

The new A350-1000 is configured with a tri-class cabin, capable of carrying up to 382 passengers. It is expected to enhance Philippine Airlines’ long-haul service, particularly on its transpacific routes, connecting the Philippines with key international destinations. With Rolls-Royce Trent XWB-97 engines, the A350-1000 is designed to be ultra-efficient, offering up to 25% lower fuel burn and CO₂ emissions compared to previous-generation aircraft. Additionally, the aircraft is certified to operate with sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) blends, further supporting the airline’s sustainability goals.

Strengthening Global Competitiveness

The arrival of the A350-1000 is described by Philippine Airlines executives as a transformational step in modernizing its long-haul fleet. This addition boosts the airline’s total fleet to 82 aircraft, reinforcing its ability to compete globally by offering cutting-edge aircraft that combine sustainability, efficiency, and passenger comfort. The A350-1000’s lower operating costs and environmental benefits will also provide Philippine Airlines with a competitive edge as it expands its global network.

The entry of the A350-1000 into Southeast Asia highlights the growing demand among airlines for ultra-efficient, long-range widebody aircraft. The A350-1000 not only supports fleet renewal but also brings substantial sustainability gains. As airlines worldwide focus on reducing their carbon footprints, the A350-1000’s ability to operate with sustainable aviation fuels positions it as an ideal solution for achieving environmental targets while also enhancing network flexibility.

As more airlines adopt next-generation aircraft like the A350-1000, the future of aviation will see improved flight efficiency, lower emissions, and more sustainable travel experiences. Philippine Airlines, with its ongoing fleet expansion and commitment to sustainability, is at the forefront of this transformation, positioning itself as a leader in sustainable aviation.

The delivery of the Airbus A350-1000 to Philippine Airlines is not only a significant development for the airline but also for the broader aviation industry and global tourism. As the A350-1000 enters service on long-haul routes, it will enhance global connectivity, making it easier for travelers to access destinations across the globe, particularly in Asia, North America, and Europe. This will encourage increased tourism flows, foster business relationships, and drive economic growth in various regions.

In addition, the aircraft’s sustainability features will play an essential role in shaping the future of green aviation, as the aviation industry continues to prioritize environmentally friendly travel options. The ability to operate with sustainable aviation fuels aligns with the growing demand for eco-conscious travel, allowing airlines to meet global sustainability goals while enhancing operational efficiency.

Philippine Airlines Leads in Sustainability and Innovation

The delivery of the Airbus A350-1000 signals a crucial milestone in Philippine Airlines journey toward sustainability, efficiency, and global competitiveness. The airline is promoting sustainable aviation and embracing cutting-edge technology in order to enhance its long-haul service and contribute to the future of green aviation. Given the new aircraft, Philippine Airlines can offer passengers traveling on its long-haul routes greater comfort, an environmentally sensitive, and innovative travel experience. Undoubtedly, the introduction of the A350-1000 will have a positive impact on the airline’s positioning in the global scenario and the aviation industry at large as it evolves toward greener practices. Increasing connectivity and greener features aboard the A350-1000 shape the future of flying around the world and contribute toward the sustainable development of aviation.

text:
Die usbekische Fluggesellschaft Qanot Sharq hat ihren ersten von insgesamt vier bestellten Airbus A321XLR übernommen. Die Auslieferung erfolgte am 19. Dezember 2025 in Hamburg im Rahmen eines langfristigen Leasingvertrags mit Air Lease Corporation.

Mit der Indienststellung wird Qanot Sharq zum Erstbetreiber des A321XLR in Zentralasien und der GUS. Das Flugzeug soll zur Flottenmodernisierung beitragen und den Ausbau des internationalen Streckennetzes ermöglichen. Geplant sind unter anderem neue Verbindungen nach Sanya und Busan sowie nach New York mit Zwischenstopp in Budapest.

Der Airbus A321XLR wird von CFM LEAP-1A-Triebwerken angetrieben und ist mit 190 Sitzen in einer Zwei-Klassen-Konfiguration ausgestattet. Die Kabine umfasst 16 Full-Flat-Sitze in der Business Class und 174 Sitze in der Economy Class. Zum Ausstattungsumfang gehören die Airbus-Airspace-Kabine mit vergrößerten Gepäckfächern, In-Seat-Konnektivität für alle Passagiere sowie ein modernes LED-Lichtsystem.

Der A321XLR ist die Langstreckenversion der A320neo-Familie und erreicht eine Reichweite von bis zu 4.700 nautischen Meilen. Gegenüber dem A321LR bietet er rund 15 Prozent mehr Reichweite und weist im Vergleich zu Flugzeugen der vorherigen Generation einen um etwa 30 Prozent niedrigeren Treibstoffverbrauch pro Sitz auf. Zudem reduziert das Muster Lärm- und Stickoxidemissionen. Airbus verzeichnet für den A321XLR bislang mehr als 500 Bestellungen.

Wie alle Airbus-Flugzeuge ist auch der A321XLR bereits für den Betrieb mit bis zu 50 Prozent Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) zugelassen. Airbus strebt an, bis 2030 alle Flugzeugtypen für den Betrieb mit 100 Prozent SAF freizugeben.

title: A Year in Procurement Stories: Looking Back on Q1
description:
With 10 million social enterprises globally generating US$2tn annually, the message was clear: procurement professionals hold considerable power in directing resources toward equitable outcomes.
The bottleneck revealed a fundamental procurement challenge – securing diverse, sustainable feedstock whilst building logistics networks capable of supporting global distribution.
Houthi attacks in the Red Sea forced shipping companies to reroute vessels around Africa's Cape of Good Hope, avoiding the Suez Canal entirely.

If the Red Sea crisis tested maritime logistics, infrastructure vulnerability exposed different weaknesses.
text:
The first quarter of 2025 unfolded as a defining period for global procurement – marked by competing priorities of equity and efficiency, regulatory upheaval and resilience tests that challenged even the most prepared organisations.

The conversation began with vision. The World Economic Forum, alongside Deloitte and the Schwab Foundation, released research spotlighting equity's role in green and digital transformation.

WEF: The Role of Equity in Green & Digital Transformation

The report emphasised that social enterprises – businesses prioritising impact over profit – could be instrumental in ensuring inclusive growth during these transitions. With 10 million social enterprises globally generating US$2tn annually, the message was clear: procurement professionals hold considerable power in directing resources toward equitable outcomes.

Yet vision alone wouldn't sustain progress. The aviation sector grappled with translating sustainable ambitions into operational reality as sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) confronted scaling challenges.

Can Aviation Overcome SAF Scaling and Cost Challenges?

Despite offering an 80% reduction in lifecycle emissions, SAF production remained hampered by feedstock scarcity, concentrated production facilities and costs exceeding traditional jet fuel.

Marie Owens Thomsen, IATA's Senior Vice President of Sustainability, articulated the urgency: "We need the whole world to produce as much renewable energy as possible for everybody. Airlines simply want to access their fair share of that output."

The bottleneck revealed a fundamental procurement challenge – securing diverse, sustainable feedstock whilst building logistics networks capable of supporting global distribution.

Meanwhile, businesses faced more immediate concerns as political transitions reshaped cost structures. When President Donald Trump took office, proposed tariffs on imports from Canada and Mexico threatened to raise US grocery prices and disrupt established sourcing strategies.

How Costco Wholesale Will Deal With Tariffs Uncertainty

Costco's response illustrated pragmatic procurement leadership.

CFO Gary Millerchip acknowledged the challenge candidly: "Tariffs raise costs so that's not something that we see as a positive in general."

Yet the company's approach – pulling forward inventory, working with vendors to mitigate costs, exploring alternative sourcing locations and pivoting SKUs when value disappeared – demonstrated how experienced procurement teams navigate policy uncertainty.

His predecessor's wisdom echoed through the strategy: "When it rains, it rains on everybody."

Andreas Rasche, Professor at Copenhagen Business School, expressed concern: "This is very disappointing and not at all proportionate. The document gives no evidence-based reasons for the changes."

For procurement teams, the implications were significant – reduced access to sustainability data could create blind spots in responsible sourcing efforts, particularly in complex global networks.

Regulatory upheaval wasn't confined to Brussels. In the UK, plans to abolish NHS England and integrate its functions into the Department of Health marked a pivotal shift in healthcare procurement.

NHS England Reform: What Does It Mean for Procurement?

Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer positioned the move as streamlining administration, yet the restructuring threatened to disrupt ongoing procurement reforms and delay purchasing of essential medicines and medical devices.

With approximately 9,000 job losses expected and a £7bn deficit to manage, procurement teams faced budgetary constraints whilst navigating decentralised decision-making through local Integrated Care Boards. The challenge became clear: achieving efficiency improvements without undermining supplier relationships or equitable patient care.

Beyond regulatory shifts, physical disruptions tested supply chain resilience. Houthi attacks in the Red Sea forced shipping companies to reroute vessels around Africa's Cape of Good Hope, avoiding the Suez Canal entirely.

How the Shipping Crisis in the Red Sea is Impacting Trade

Container shipments through the region dropped 75% as companies navigated the trade-off between security risks and the costs of detours adding 10 to 14 days to transit times.

Xeneta's Chief Analyst Peter Sand stated: "All ships transiting the Suez Canal must sail through the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden and the Houthi militia has made clear that any vessel is a target."

The crisis sent shipping rates soaring and forced businesses relying on just-in-time manufacturing to reconsider fundamental assumptions about supply chain design.

If the Red Sea crisis tested maritime logistics, infrastructure vulnerability exposed different weaknesses. A fire at an electrical substation forced Heathrow Airport's closure until midnight on 21 March, affecting more than 1,300 flights.

How the Heathrow Airport Closure Impacted Supply Chains

The incident disrupted not just passenger travel but cargo operations at the UK's largest port by value, handling more than 1.6 million metric tonnes of freight annually.

John Manners-Bell, CEO of Transport Intelligence, criticised the apparent oversight: "A fire at a single power sub-station bringing one of the world's busiest airports to a complete halt? Someone has been asleep at the wheel."

The event served as a stark reminder that even the most sophisticated supply chains remain vulnerable to infrastructure failures beyond procurement's direct control.

These individual disruptions converged into a broader pattern. QIMA's 2025 Sourcing Survey revealed that three-quarters of businesses expected supply chain disruptions to persist, whilst nearly 90% still lacked full visibility into their supply chains.

Businesses Dealing with Escalating Supply Chain Disruptions

Companies responded by diversifying sourcing strategies – two-thirds maintained or expanded Chinese supplier operations whilst half of US businesses shifted volumes closer to home through nearshoring.

Air New Zealand is set to make a huge impact on tourism in 2026 with its exciting route expansion. Queenstown joins Auckland, Wellington, Rarotonga, and more in this new network, boosting access to New Zealand’s iconic destinations and the Pacific Islands. This expansion will make it easier for travelers to explore the breathtaking landscapes of Queenstown, the vibrant culture of Auckland, the beautiful waterfront of Wellington, and the tropical paradise of Rarotonga. Air New Zealand’s strategic routes aim to turbocharge tourism, making these incredible destinations more accessible than ever before. By enhancing connectivity between Australia, New Zealand, and the Pacific, this expansion promises to open up new opportunities for travelers, businesses, and local economies alike. Whether seeking adventure, relaxation, or culture, this route network will undoubtedly draw more visitors to these remarkable locations.

Queenstown: A Thrilling Destination Now Within Reach

Queenstown, the adventure capital of New Zealand, is known for its breathtaking scenery, ski resorts, and outdoor activities. This beautiful town on the South Island of New Zealand is now more accessible than ever, thanks to Air New Zealand’s new seasonal route between Brisbane and Queenstown. This flight, which starts in June 2026, offers travelers a chance to experience Queenstown’s stunning landscapes without the hassle of long travel times.

New Seasonal Route: Brisbane ↔ Queenstown

Route Type: Seasonal Non-Stop Flight

End Date: October 23, 2026

Key Features: Air New Zealand’s new direct flight reduces travel time and offers easy access to Queenstown’s ski fields, vineyards, and adventure tourism options. For outdoor enthusiasts, Queenstown offers skiing, bungee jumping, hiking, and skydiving, making it a must-visit destination.

The route also boosts tourism in Queenstown, helping travelers from Australia access the iconic New Zealand destination for the winter season. This service will make exploring Queenstown even easier, allowing travelers to experience the spectacular alpine views and world-class adventure activities.

Auckland: New Connectivity with Brisbane

Auckland, New Zealand’s largest city, is a hub of culture, commerce, and cuisine. Air New Zealand is ramping up its services from Brisbane to Auckland with an increase in capacity for flights between these two vibrant cities. The additional flights provide more opportunities for business travelers and tourists alike to visit this exciting destination.

Increased Capacity: Brisbane ↔ Auckland

Route Type: Increased Frequency and Capacity

Start Date: 2026 (Peak Season)

Key Features: The increased capacity between Brisbane and Auckland helps meet the rising demand for this popular route. Auckland offers a variety of activities, from visiting the famous Sky Tower to experiencing the vibrant waterfront. Visitors can explore Auckland’s thriving arts scene, lush parks, and multicultural dining experiences.

The added flights will make it easier for travelers to access Auckland’s beaches, nature reserves, and world-class shopping districts. Whether you are in Auckland for business or leisure, the enhanced flight schedule will provide flexibility and convenience.

Wellington: New Flights from Brisbane to New Zealand’s Capital

Wellington, the capital city of New Zealand, is known for its rich cultural heritage, stunning waterfront, and scenic hills. Air New Zealand’s expanded route from Brisbane to Wellington is another fantastic way for travelers to explore this charming city.

Enhanced Route: Brisbane ↔ Wellington

Route Type: Seasonal Capacity Increase

Start Date: 2026

Key Features: Wellington is famous for its picturesque harbor and vibrant arts scene. It is the perfect place to discover New Zealand’s history, culture, and natural beauty. The increased flights between Brisbane and Wellington will help boost tourism, making it easier for travelers to visit museums, dine in exceptional restaurants, and enjoy the city’s famous festivals and events.

Wellington’s unique location, nestled between mountains and the sea, offers breathtaking views at every turn. The new flight capacity will allow more visitors to experience the charm of New Zealand’s capital.

Christchurch: Gateway to the Southern Alps and Beyond

Christchurch, known as the “Garden City,” is located on the South Island of New Zealand. With its proximity to the Southern Alps and Canterbury Plains, Christchurch is the gateway to adventure tourism. Air New Zealand’s new seasonal route from Christchurch to Rarotonga will provide even more opportunities to explore this unique destination.

New Seasonal Route: Christchurch ↔ Rarotonga

Route Type: Seasonal Non-Stop Flight

The new Christchurch-Rarotonga flight connects the South Island to one of the most beautiful tropical islands in the Pacific. Rarotonga, with its turquoise lagoons and white-sand beaches, is a paradise for beach lovers and those looking to relax in a serene environment.

This route is ideal for those looking to combine the cultural experiences of New Zealand with the tranquility of the Cook Islands. The new service will offer easier access to both regions, allowing for a unique vacation experience that mixes adventure and relaxation.

Rarotonga: A Tropical Paradise Awaiting Discovery

Rarotonga, the largest of the Cook Islands, is a beautiful tropical island that offers an idyllic getaway. The new seasonal flight from Christchurch to Rarotonga will make it easier for travelers to access this stunning destination, known for its crystal-clear waters, vibrant coral reefs, and rich Polynesian culture.

New Seasonal Route: Christchurch ↔ Rarotonga

Route Type: Seasonal Non-Stop Flight

End Date: October 2026

Key Features: Rarotonga is a dream destination for those looking for a tropical escape. The island is famous for its coral reefs, beautiful beaches, and outdoor activities such as snorkeling, hiking, and cultural tours. The new flight from Christchurch opens up this paradise to more travelers, giving them the opportunity to explore one of the most pristine islands in the Pacific.

With its easy access via Christchurch, Rarotonga is set to become even more popular with both Kiwi travelers and those from further afield.

How Air New Zealand’s New Routes Will Transform Travel

Air New Zealand’s new and expanded routes are not just about increasing convenience for travelers – they are also about opening up new opportunities for tourism, business, and cultural exchange between New Zealand, Australia, and the Pacific Islands. Each new route brings with it the potential for enhanced connectivity, increased tourism, and better access to some of the most beautiful and vibrant regions in the Southern Hemisphere.

Table: Summary of New Routes by Air New Zealand

The Economic Impact of Air New Zealand’s New Routes

One of the most significant aspects of Air New Zealand’s route expansion is its economic impact on both New Zealand and Australia. New routes generally bring an increase in tourism, which boosts local businesses, job creation, and infrastructure growth.

For Queenstown, the new seasonal route from Brisbane not only makes it more accessible for adventure tourists but also enhances local employment in the tourism and hospitality sectors. Air New Zealand’s additional capacity on routes between Brisbane and Auckland, Wellington, and Christchurch opens up more opportunities for international business travelers, fostering cross-border trade and collaboration.

The addition of the Christchurch ↔ Rarotonga seasonal flight will stimulate growth in the Pacific Islands tourism sector as well, bringing more travelers to Rarotonga and enhancing connections between New Zealand and the Cook Islands. This will also foster more cultural exchanges and increase awareness of Pacific Island tourism globally.

Sustainability and Air New Zealand’s Commitment to the Environment

Air New Zealand is renowned for its commitment to sustainability and reducing its carbon footprint. With the addition of these new routes, the airline is working hard to implement eco-friendly initiatives to ensure the growth of air travel is balanced with environmental responsibility.

These efforts include:

Sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), which reduces carbon emissions from flights.

More fuel-efficient aircraft, which Air New Zealand has been integrating into its fleet over recent years.

Carbon offset programs, allowing passengers to voluntarily offset their travel-related carbon emissions.

Through these sustainability measures, Air New Zealand is not only enhancing connectivity but also contributing to the broader effort to make air travel more environmentally conscious.

Traveler Tips: Making the Most of These New Routes

With the launch of these new routes, it’s important for travelers to take full advantage of the opportunity. Here are some tips to make the most out of Air New Zealand’s new services:

Book Early for Best Prices: Air New Zealand typically offers the best deals for early bookings. Take advantage of this to save money on your flight.

Explore New Destinations: With these new routes, travelers now have the chance to experience Queenstown’s adventure tourism, Auckland’s thriving city life, and Rarotonga’s tropical beauty in a more convenient and affordable way.

Take Advantage of Air New Zealand’s Loyalty Programs: Travelers can benefit from the airline’s Frequent Flyer Program, which offers points and rewards for frequent travelers.

Connect with Local Activities: Once at your destination, make sure to explore not only the popular tourist spots but also local hidden gems. For example, in Wellington, you can explore lesser-known nature reserves and cultural museums.

What Makes These New Routes Stand Out

Each of Air New Zealand’s new routes is carefully designed to meet the growing demand for easy access to New Zealand and the Pacific Islands. But what sets them apart?

Queenstown ↔ Brisbane: The fact that this route is a seasonal, direct flight makes it highly attractive to adventure travelers who want to visit Queenstown’s ski resorts, bungy jumping locations, and vineyards without the hassle of long travel times.

Brisbane ↔ Auckland/Wellington/Christchurch: The increased capacity on these routes ensures that business and leisure travelers alike can find more flight options to these vibrant cities, making it easier to attend business meetings, festivals, and explore New Zealand’s natural beauty.

Christchurch ↔ Rarotonga: This route directly connects two beautiful destinations that are often overlooked. Rarotonga’s pristine beaches and crystal-clear waters make it a perfect getaway for those seeking tropical relaxation after exploring Christchurch’s gardens and mountain ranges.

Each of these routes allows travelers to experience New Zealand and the Pacific Islands in a more seamless and connected way, making these regions more accessible to global tourists.

Looking Ahead: More Routes and Future Expansion Plans

While Air New Zealand is making significant strides with its new routes, it’s clear that this expansion is only the beginning. The airline has indicated that it plans to continue expanding its network to meet the increasing demand for travel between Australia, New Zealand, and the Pacific Islands.

Future route expansions could include:

More seasonal or year-round routes connecting New Zealand with other Pacific Islands such as Tahiti, Fiji, and the Solomon Islands.

Additional connections between New Zealand and Asia, expanding options for tourists and business travelers who wish to visit both regions.

More flights to North America and Europe, offering travelers new, convenient ways to travel between these major continents.

Air New Zealand’s continued growth is an exciting development for both the aviation industry and tourism. As the world continues to recover from the global pandemic, Air New Zealand is setting the stage for a vibrant and interconnected future for international travel.

Conclusion: Why Air New Zealand’s New Routes Are a Game-Changer for Travel

Air New Zealand’s newly launched and enhanced routes are more than just a means of getting from one place to another. They represent new opportunities for travelers to explore the beautiful destinations of New Zealand and the Pacific Islands. From the thrill of Queenstown’s adventure tourism to the tranquil beaches of Rarotonga, these routes make travel easier, faster, and more enjoyable.

Whether you’re an adventure seeker, a culture lover, or someone looking to unwind in a tropical paradise, Air New Zealand’s new routes are designed to make these dream destinations more accessible. The added capacity on existing routes between Brisbane and Auckland, Wellington, and Christchurch further solidifies Air New Zealand’s position as the leading carrier in the region.

As the airline continues to expand, these new connections open the door to more amazing travel experiences, and we can only expect even more exciting developments in the future.

text:
United Aircraft Corporation (UAC) has conducted the maiden flight of a newly built Tupolev Tu-214 from its manufacturing site in Kazan. The flight marks the restart of the assembly entirely with domestic components, as part of ongoing efforts to replace foreign suppliers.

The maiden flight lasted 1 hour and 10 minutes. The aircraft, which subsequently flew from Kazan to Minsk on 17 December, supports the Russian government’s import-substitution policy for the aviation sector.

This Tu-214 was initially reported as intended for Tatarstan-based UVT-Aero. However, UVT-Aero has stated it will focus on other aircraft types in coordination with the federal air transport regulator Rosaviatsia.

UVT-Aero’s chief, Pyotr Trubaev, has said the carrier is examining the Ilyushin Il-114-300 and the Yakovlev SJ-100, both featuring significant domestic content. Aeroflot Group previously considered adding Tu-214s but is reportedly prioritizing MC-21s instead, said Flight Global.

State lessor GTLK committed to over 40 Tu-214s last year, reflecting broader fleet modernization efforts. Red Wings has recently taken delivery of Tu-214s, but these were older aircraft refurbished from storage rather than newly manufactured.

The Russian Ministry of Industry and Trade launched a restoration and airworthiness program for the Tu-204/214, Il-96, and An-124 in October 2022, initially targeting 12 aircraft for return to service by 2024.

The program has been extended to 2027 to accommodate delivery delays and modernization needs, underlining the Tu-214’s role in sustaining Russian domestic air transport.

The Tu-214, developed as a variant of the Tu-204 and first flown in 1996, features higher gross weight and additional fuel capacity compared to its predecessor. It is produced at the Kazan Aviation Plant, while the Tu-204 is assembled in Ulyanovsk with a different door configuration.

Terminado o Air Invictus, a Faculdade de Economia da Universidade do Porto fará a avaliação da sua relevância económica, aferindo efeitos, impacto, emprego e outras variáveis.
text:
Outra novidade é o alargamento da iniciativa a Matosinhos e à Maia. “Esta marca e o novo conceito têm uma enorme capacidade para trazer ao Grande Porto um milhão de pessoas, das quais se espera que cerca de 300 mil sejam estrangeiras”, indica a empresa portuguesa Bravimaginação, responsável pela organização.

O certame está orçamentado em 7,5 milhões de euros, com uma parte a ser financiada por dinheiros públicos e outra por patrocinadores, mas a participação do público é gratuita. “O Air Invictus está alinhado com a “Estratégia 2035″, visando parcerias que estão a ser estabelecidas com países do mundo árabe e da Ásia, entre outros mercados”, é adiantado.

Os autarcas Luís Filipe Menezes e Pedro Duarte são dois dos principais entusiastas do regresso dos aviões ao Douro. Menezes falou do assunto durante a campanha e logo após a sua eleição para a presidência da autarquia gaiense, sempre com o objetivo acolher iniciativas a abranger as duas autarquias.

O programa engloba corrida de aviões, acrobacias aéreas, demonstrações militares pela Força Aérea Portuguesa, demonstrações policiais pelo Grupo de Operações Especiais/PSP, um festival de aeromodelismo, festivais de drones com a tentativa de bater o recorde da Europa na praia do Titan (Matosinhos); exposições de meios aéreos e militares com batismos de voo e festivais de música, entre outras iniciativas.

A Força Aérea Portuguesa é o parceiro oficial do Air Invictus e irá envolver diversas aeronaves como o KC 390, C 295, F 16 e os Super Tucanos. Haverá um F16 colocado na margem de Gaia e dois outros aviões do lado do Porto.

Um dos eventos associados é o “Eyes in the sky”, a primeira feira e “summit” da indústria de defesa aérea e aeroespacial, que irá mostrar na Alfândega do Porto, em 5000 m2 de exposição, “o que de melhor as empresas portuguesas estão a inovar, produzir e exportar para todo o mundo, e que trará ao nosso país visitantes, expositores, especialistas e cientistas para várias conferências”. Estará patente até ao dia 23 de junho. Haverá uma forte promoção internacional com ativações, campanhas na televisão e nas redes sociais, entre outras.

O regresso das aeronaves ao Douro “engloba uma componente de literacia aeronáutica para as escolas da região Norte, com visitas, palestras, contacto com pilotos e aviões, bem como batismos de voo, onde se pretende que os mais novos voltem a ganhar a paixão pelo espaço e pela aviação”, como explica a organização.

A organização refere que um forte dispositivo ficará estacionado no Aeródromo Vilar de Luz, na Maia, estando a ser equacionada a possibilidade de organizar um encontro mundial de “Chipmunks”, que comemoram 75 anos em 2026. Certa é a vinda dos “Warbirds”, aviões da segunda guerra mundial e que estarão em exposição no concelho maiato. O município será o centro das operações, com acrobacias, descolagens e aterragens, e batismos de voo. A organização espera que mais de 200 mil pessoas visitem o aeródromo no evento.

A Força Aérea Portuguesa vai montar um foguetão em plena Alfândega, o que irá gerar a curiosidade de milhares de visitantes, entre os quais muitos oriundos das visitas de escolas. Terminado o Air Invictus, a Faculdade de Economia da Universidade do Porto fará a avaliação da sua relevância económica, aferindo efeitos, impacto, emprego e outras variáveis. Está prevista a presença da imprensa estrangeira, bem como a transmissão nacional e internacional dos eventos.
